verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:1
verses.text: Second Part  Aphrahat the Persian Sage.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:3
verses.text: Name of Author of Demonstrations long Unknown.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:4
verses.text: —The author of the Demonstrations, eight of which appear (for the first time in an English version) in the present volume, has a singular literary history.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:5
verses.text: By nationality a Persian, in an age when Zoroastrianism was the religion of Persia, he wrote in Syriac as a Christian theologian.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:6
verses.text: His writings, now known to us as the works of Aphrahat, were remembered, cited, translated, and transcribed for at least two centuries after his death; but his proper name seems to have been for a time forgotten, so that in the mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:7
verses.text: of the fifth and sixth centuries the Demonstrations are described as composed by "the Persian Sage," or "Mar Jacob the Persian Sage;" and a writer of the eighth century, who had made a minute study of these writings and ascertained their date, admits that he has been unable to find out "who or what he was, his rank in the Church, his name or abode".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:8
verses.text: Not only so, but the name Jacob assigned (rightly or wrongly) to him has led to a confusion of identity.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:9
verses.text: His works have been ascribed for many hundred years—from a date not long after their composition down to quite recent times, to an earlier Jacob, the famous and saintly Bishop of Nisibis in the days of Constantine the Great.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:10
verses.text: It is not until the tenth century that the true name of "the Persian Sage" emerges to light as Aphrahat, by which he is unhesitatingly designated by several well informed and accurate authorities of that and the three succeeding centuries.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:11
verses.text: , and under which he is known to modern scholars.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:13
verses.text: Their Subjects, and Arrangement.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:14
verses.text: —The Demonstrations are twenty-two in number, after the number of the letters of the Syriac alphabet, each of them beginning with the letter to which it corresponds in order.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:15
verses.text: The first ten form a group by themselves, and are somewhat earlier in date than those which follow:  they deal with Christian graces, hopes, and duties, as appears from their titles:—"Concerning Faith, Charity, Fasting, Prayer, Wars, Monks, Penitents, the Resurrection, Humility, Pastors".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:16
verses.text: Of those that compose the later group, three relate to the Jews ("Concerning Circumcision, the Passover, the Sabbath"); followed by one described as "Hortatory," which seems to be a letter of rebuke addressed by Aphrahat, on behalf of a Synod of Bishops, to the clergy and people of Seleucia and Ctesiphon; after which the Jewish series is resumed in five discourses, "Concerning Divers Meals, The Call of the Gentiles, Jesus the Messiah, Virginity, the Dispersion of Israel".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:17
verses.text: The three last are of the same general character as the first ten,—"Concerning Almsgiving, Persecution, Death, and the Latter Times".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:18
verses.text: To this collection is subjoined a twenty-third Demonstration, supplementary to the rest, "Concerning the Grape," under which title is signified the blessing transmitted from the beginning through Christ, in allusion to the words of Isaiah, "As the grape is found in the cluster and one saith, Destroy it not" (lxv.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:20
verses.text: This treatise embodies a chronological disquisition of some importance.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:22
verses.text: Dates of Composition.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:23
verses.text: —Of the dates at which they were written, these discourses supply conclusive evidence.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:24
verses.text: At the end of section 5 of Demonstr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:25
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:26
verses.text: (Concerning Wars), the author reckons the years from the era of Alexander (b.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:27
verses.text: c.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:28
verses.text: 311) to the time of his writing as 648.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:29
verses.text: He wrote therefore in a.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:30
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:31
verses.text: 337—the year of the death of Constantine the Great.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:32
verses.text: Demonst.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:33
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:34
verses.text: is formally dated in its last section, "in the month Shebat.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:35
verses.text: in the year 655" (that is, a.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:36
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:38
verses.text: More fully, in closing the alphabetic series (XXII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:39
verses.text: 25) he informs us that the above dates apply to the two groups—the first ten being written in 337; the twelve that follow, in 344.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:40
verses.text: Finally, the supplementary discourse "Concerning the Grape" was written (as stated, XXIII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:41
verses.text: 69) in July, 345.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:42
verses.text: Thus the entire work was completed within nine years,—five years before the middle of the fourth century,—before the composition of the earliest work of Ephraim of which the date can be determined with certainty.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:44
verses.text: Extent and Limits of their Circulation.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:45
verses.text: —These Demonstrations, though they fell far short of attaining the unbounded popularity which was the lot of the countless Hymns and Homilies of Ephraim, appear to have won for themselves a recognized place in Syriac literature.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:46
verses.text: It is true that, in striking contrast with the overwhelming numbers of mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:47
verses.text: containing portions, great or small, of Ephraim's works, which are to be met with in nearly every collection of Syriac written remains, one complete and two incomplete copies are all that have reached us of this series of twenty-three treatises; and extracts or quotations from them very rarely occur.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:48
verses.text: Yet it is clear that compositions which were thought worthy at an early date of translation into at least one foreign tongue, must have had some considerable reputation in the country of their origin; and it may be presumed that these two or three mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:49
verses.text: (of the fifth and sixth centuries), are the survivors of a fairly large number of which the majority have perished.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:50
verses.text: The Armenian translation is probably the earliest evidence now extant of the circulation (though under a wrong ascription of authorship) of the Demonstrations, of which it comprises nineteen.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:51
verses.text: Armenian scholars seem to agree in the belief that it was made in the fifth century, before its original was more than a hundred years in being.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:52
verses.text: An Ethiopic translation of the discourse "On Wars" is extant, but there is no evidence that it formed part of a version extending to all or any of the remaining twenty-two, nor is its date even approximately determinable.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:53
verses.text: The manuscript evidence hardly reaches so far back as that of the Armenian version.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:54
verses.text: The oldest extant ms.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:55
verses.text: of these discourses (Add.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:56
verses.text: 17182 of the British Museum) contains the first ten, and is dated 474.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:57
verses.text: With it is bound up (under the same number) a second, dated 512, containing the remaining thirteen.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:58
verses.text: A third (Add.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:59
verses.text: 14619) of the sixth century likewise, exhibits the whole series.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:60
verses.text: A fourth (Orient, 1017), more recent by eight centuries, will be mentioned farther on.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:61
verses.text: Of the three early mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:62
verses.text: , the first designates the author as "the Persian Sage" merely, as does also the third:  the second prefixes his name as "Mar Jacob the Persian Sage".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:63
verses.text: Among Syriac authors, the first to show an acquaintance with these treatises, at a date prior to that of the earliest of these mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:64
verses.text: , is Isaac of Antioch, known as "the Great," whose literary activity belongs to the first half of the fifth century.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:65
verses.text: In his works passages have been pointed out which are evidently borrowed with slight change from the Demonstrations,—especially from that Concerning Fasting, and (though less distinctly) from that Concerning Faith.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:66
verses.text: The imitation, however, is tacit, and Isaac nowhere names the work (or its author) whence he derived the illustrations and even the expressions he uses in treating of these topics.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:67
verses.text: Before the close of the same century, we find evidence that they were known—by repute, though apparently no farther—to a Latin writer of Western Europe, Gennadius of Marseilles, the continuator of St.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:68
verses.text: Jerome's work De Viris Illustribus, who wrote about the year 495.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:69
verses.text: Though mistaken (as will presently be shown) about their parentage, and incorrectly informed as to their number (which he supposes to be twenty-six), Gennadius states their titles with such an approach to accuracy, as to leave no room for doubt that the discourses he describes are those of which we now treat.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:70
verses.text: He shows himself aware that they are in Syriac, but gives no hint that he has ever seen them, or that he is able to read them.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:71
verses.text: In the seventh century, or (however) early in the eighth, tokens appear of a revival of interest in them.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:72
verses.text: Georgius, "Bishop of the Arabs," a Jacobite prelate, having been applied to by one Joshua an anchorite for information concerning the "Epistles" (as he styles them) of "the Persian Sage" and their authorship, wrote (in Syriac) in the year 714 a very full and elaborate reply, in which he cites at length passages from several of them, including those (above referred to) in which the dates of writing are stated with precision,—and he infers from these dates, that the author, of whose name he professes himself to be ignorant, wrote too early to be a disciple of Ephraim.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:73
verses.text: To this inference we may safely assent, even though we hold that Ephraim wrote and taught earlier in the century than Georgius endeavours to place him.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:74
verses.text: The point to be noted is, that this learned and acute writer, though he had by careful study made himself familiar with the Demonstrations, neither knows, nor can guess at, the name of their author, nor can he record any tradition concerning his identity.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:75
verses.text: He can only tell what he has learned from their contents, that they were written from 337 to 345, by one who was a monk, and a cleric; and that they were characterized by certain peculiarities of doctrine.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:77
verses.text: Ascribed to Jacob of Nisibis.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:78
verses.text: —Thus it appears that the series of discourses now known as the Demonstrations of Aphrahat, were imitated, and transcribed, and translated, into Armenian, and their titles cited by a Latin biographer, and their contents minutely investigated by an able critic, within the four centuries that followed the time of their composition; while through all that long period the name of Aphrahat had passed out of memory, and the "Persian Sage" simply, or else with the addition of an ambiguous and misleading name, "Jacob, the Persian Sage," was the designation by which their author was usually known.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:79
verses.text: As we have seen, the scribes of two mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:80
verses.text: , of the fifth and sixth centuries, and Georgius in the early eighth, confine themselves to the former; and the scribe of the sixth, thirty-eight years later than the earlier of the other two, uses the latter.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:81
verses.text: Misled by it, the Armenian translator, and Gennadius in his biographical work, fell into the error of identifying the Jacob who wrote the Demonstrations with a namesake, the earlier and more conspicuous Jacob of Nisibis, of whom we have had occasion to speak in treating of the life of Ephraim.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:82
verses.text: But of this celebrated personage no writings are recorded, nor was he a Persian, but a native of Nisibis (in his time a city of the Roman Empire), in 338, seven years before the completion of the treatises in question.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:83
verses.text: As Jacob of Nisibis is thus too early to be the author of them, so, on the other hand, Jacob of Sarug, whom Assemani suggested in correcting the mistake of Gennadius, is too late; for he was not born till more than a century after the date of the last Demonstration.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:85
verses.text: Reappearance of the Name of Aphrahat.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:86
verses.text: —It is not until some years after the mid-die of the tenth century, that the "Persian Sage" first appears under his proper name,—of which, though as it appears generally forgotten in the Syriac world of letters, a tradition had survived.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:87
verses.text: —The Nestorian Bar-Bahlul (circ.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:88
verses.text: 963) in his Syro-Arabic Lexicon, writes thus:—"Aphrahat [mentioned] in the Book of Paradise, is the Persian Sage, as they record".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:89
verses.text: —So too, in the eleventh century, Elias of Nisibis (Barsinaeus, d.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:90
verses.text: 1049), embodies in his Chronography, a table, compiled from Demonstr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:91
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:92
verses.text: , of the chronography from the Creation to the "Era of Alexander" (b.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:93
verses.text: c.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:94
verses.text: 311), which he describes as "The years of the House of Adam, according to the opinion of Aphrahat, the Persian Sage".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:95
verses.text: —To the like effect, but with fuller information, the great light of the mediaeval Jacobite Church, Gregory Barhebraeus (d.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:96
verses.text: 1286), in Part I.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:97
verses.text: of his Ecclesiastical Chronicle, in enumerating the orthodox contemporaries of Athanasius, mentions, after Ephraim, "the Persian Sage who wrote the Book of Demonstrations;" and again in Part II.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:98
verses.text: , supplies his name under a slightly different form, as one who "was of note in the time of Papas the Catholicus," "the Persian Sage by name Pharhad, of whom there are extant a book of admonition [al.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:99
verses.text: , admonitions] in Syriac, and twenty-two Epistles according to the letters of the alphabet".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:100
verses.text: Here we have not only the name and description of the personage in question, but a fairly accurate account of his works, under the titles by which the mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:101
verses.text: describe them, Epistles and Demonstrations;—and moreover a sufficient indication of his date, in agreement with that which the Demonstrations claim:  for one who began to write in 337 must have lived in the closing years of the life of Papas (who died in 334), and in the earlier years of the life of Ephraim.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:102
verses.text: So yet again, a generation later, the learned Nestorian prelate, Ebedjesu, in his Catalogue of Syrian ecclesiastical authors, writes, "Aphrahat, the Persian Sage, composed two volumes with Homilies that are according to the alphabet".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:103
verses.text: Here once more the name and designation are given unhesitatingly, and the division of the discourses into two groups is correctly noted; but the concluding words appear to distinguish these groups from the alphabetic Homilies.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:104
verses.text: Either, therefore, we must take the preposition rendered "with" to mean "containing,"—or we must conclude that Ebedjesu's knowledge of the work was at second-hand and incorrect.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:105
verses.text: Finally, in a very late ms.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:106
verses.text: , dated 1364, is found the first or chronological part of Demonstration XXIII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:107
verses.text: , headed as follows:—"The Demonstration concerning the Grape, of the Sage Aphrahat, who is Jacob, Bishop of Mar Mathai".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:108
verses.text: Here (though the prefix "Persian" is absent) we have the author's title of "Sage"; and the identification of the "Aphrahat" of the later authorities with the "Jacob" of the earlier is not merely implied but expressly affirmed.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:109
verses.text: Here, moreover, we have what seems to account for the twofold name.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:110
verses.text: As author, he is Aphrahat; as Bishop, he is Jacob—the latter name having been no doubt assumed on his elevation to the Episcopate.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:111
verses.text: Such changes of name, at consecration, which in later ages of the Syrian Church became customary, were no doubt exceptional in the earlier period of which we are treating.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:112
verses.text: But the fact that Aphrahat was a Persian name, bestowed on him no doubt in childhood—when he was still (as will be shown presently) outside the Christian fold—a name which is supposed to signify "Chief" or "Prefect," and which may have seemed unsuited to the humility of the sacred office—supplies a reason for the substitution in its stead of a name associated with sacred history, both of the Old and of the New Testament.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:113
verses.text: Here finally we have the direct statement of what Georgius had justly inferred from the opening of Dem.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:114
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:115
verses.text: , that the writer was himself of the clergy, and in this Epistle writes as a cleric to clerics.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:116
verses.text: We have now brought together all the known authorities who yield information concerning this collection of treatises, and its author.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:117
verses.text: It remains that we should put into a connected form the facts to which they testify, and point out the inferences yielded by their notices, and by the treatises themselves.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:119
verses.text: His Nationality Persian, and Probably Heathen.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:120
verses.text: —That the author was of Persian nationality, is a point on which all the witnesses agree, except the fourteenth-century scribe of the ms.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:121
verses.text: Orient.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:122
verses.text: 1017, who however is merely silent about it.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:123
verses.text: The name Aphrahat is, as has been already said, Persian—which fact at once confirms the tradition that he belonged to Persia, and helps to account for what seems to be the reluctance of early writers to call him by a name that was foreign, unfamiliar, unsuited to his subsequent station in the Church, and superseded by one that had sacred associations.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:124
verses.text: As a Persian, he dates his writings by the years of the reign of the Persian King:  the twenty-two were completed (he says) in the thirty-fifth, the twenty-third in the thirty-sixth of the reign of Sapor.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:125
verses.text: —Again:  as a Persian of the early fourth century, it is presumable that he was not originally a Christian.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:126
verses.text: And this is apparently confirmed by the internal evidence of his own writings; for he speaks of himself as one of those "who have cast away idols, and call that a lie which our father bequeathed to us;" and again, "who ought to worship Jesus, for that He has turned away our froward minds from all superstitions of vain error, and taught us to worship one God our Father and Maker".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:127
verses.text: —But it is clear that he must have lived in a frontier region where Syriac was spoken freely; or else must have removed into a Syriac-speaking country at an early age; for the language and style of his writings are completely pure, showing no trace of foreign idiom, or even of the want of ease that betrays a foreigner writing in what is not his mother-tongue.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:128
verses.text: It is clear also that, at whatever age or under whatever circumstances he embraced Christianity, he must have taken the Christian Scriptures and Christian theology into his inmost heart and understanding as every page of his writings attests.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:130
verses.text: Evidence that he was a Cleric, and a Bishop.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:131
verses.text: —We have already seen that Georgius in his study of the Demonstrations perceived the indications which prove the writer to be of the Clergy.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:132
verses.text: He goes farther, and notes that the sixth (Concerning Monks) is evidently written by a monk.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:133
verses.text: He might have added, what is yet more important, that the fourteenth (which he rightly fixes on as evidently written by a cleric) can hardly have been written by one of lower rank than that of Bishop.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:134
verses.text: The translation of the opening sentence of this discourse (which is an Epistle to the Bishops, Clergy and people of the Church of Seleucia and Ctesiphon) is disputed; for "we being gathered together have taken counsel to write this Epistle to our brethren…the Bishops, Priests, and Deacons, and the whole Church" (XIV.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:135
verses.text: 1) may be read so as to make the "Bishops, Priests, etc.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:136
verses.text: ," either, the "we" who write,—or, the "brethren" who are written to.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:137
verses.text: Whichever construction is adopted, the fact remains that Aphrahat here writes on behalf of a body of men assembled in council, who through him admonished their "dear and beloved brethren" whom they designate (farther on) as "the Bishops, Priests and Deacons…and all the people of God who are in Seleucia and Ctesiphon".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:138
verses.text: It is not conceivable that any body of men but a synod of Bishops (with their clergy and people present and assenting) would, in that age of the Church, have taken upon itself to meet and consult and address such an epistle of admonition and implied rebuke to that great see, the seat of the "Catholicus of the East," the prelate who in the oriental hierarchy was inferior in dignity to the Antiochian Patriarch alone, and in authority almost coequal with him.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:139
verses.text: And it may be safely assumed that the writer of the Epistle was one—probably the chief—of the Bishops in whose name it is written.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:140
verses.text: If we accept the late, but internally probable, statement of the Scribe of ms.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:141
verses.text: Orient.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:142
verses.text: 1017 (above mentioned), that "the Persian Sage" was "Bishop of the monastery of Mar Mathai," we arrive at a complete explanation of the circumstances under which this Epistle was composed.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:143
verses.text: For the Bishop of Mar Mathai was Metropolitan of Nineveh, and ranked among the Bishops of "the East" only second to the Catholicus; and his province bordered on that which the Catholicus (as Metropolitan of Seleucia) held in his immediate jurisdiction.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:144
verses.text: The Bishop of Mar Mathai therefore would properly preside in a Synod of the Eastern Bishops, met to consider the disorders and discussions existing in Seleucia and its suffragan sees.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:145
verses.text: It thus becomes intelligible how an Epistle of such official character has found a place in a series of discourses of which the rest are written as from man to man merely.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:146
verses.text: The writer addresses the Bishops, Clergy, and people of Seleucia and Ctesiphon in the name of a Synod over which he was President, a Synod probably of Bishops suffragan to Nineveh, and perhaps of those of some adjacent sees.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:147
verses.text: Thus the admonition comes officially from "Mar Jacob Bishop of Mar Mathai;" but the thoughts, and language, and literary form are the production of Aphrahat personally, and he accordingly embodies it as fourteenth in his alphabetic series of twenty-two treatises, in which it is duly distinguished by its initial letter nun, the fourteenth of the Semitic alphabet.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:148
verses.text: It certainly breaks the sequence of subjects, coming after and before treatises relating to Judaism:  but for the alphabetic sequence it is essential.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:149
verses.text: —This alphabetic arrangement was overlooked or ignored (as it seems) by the Armenian translator, who has omitted four of the twenty-two and transposed others, placing the fourteenth apart from the rest,—although in Demonstr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:150
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:151
verses.text: (which however is not included in the Armenian version) the author recites all their titles, arranging them in their order, and noting that it is the order of the alphabet.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:152
verses.text: In the Syriac original the fact is beyond question that Demonstr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:153
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:154
verses.text: is an integral part of the series; and we may rely with confidence on the internal evidence it yields of the high ecclesiastical rank of the writer—evidence confirmed by, and in its turn confirming, the statement of the fourteenth-century scribe who makes him Bishop of the second see of the East.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:155
verses.text: Reverting to the subject of the Persian nationality of Aphrahat, we note that this monastery of Mar Mathai was on the eastern, that is, the Persian, side of the Tigris, not far from what once was Nineveh and is now Mosul, on the precipitous mountain Elpheph (now Maklob) where it still stands, though ruinous, and is known by the name of Sheikh Matta, and is occupied by the Metram (or Metropolitan) and a few monks.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:157
verses.text: His Writings little Concerned with Current Controversies.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:158
verses.text: —To the remoteness of his see, and probably of the place of his obvious origin and abode, from the centres of religious thought and controversy, is probably due the notable absence from these discourses of all reference to the great theological questions that had employed, and in his time were engrossing, the leading minds of Christendom.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:159
verses.text: He began to write within ten years after the Nicene Council and the Arian controversy, and the disputations that grew out of it were still ripe, and continued to abound long after.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:160
verses.text: The writings of Ephraim show how vehemently in Aphrahat's lifetime, or possibly a few years later, the theologians of Nisibis and of Edessa deemed themselves bound to strive for the Faith against Arians, Anomoeans, Apollinarians,—and not less against the surviving or revived heresy of home-grown production—that of Bardesan.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:161
verses.text: But in Seleucia and Ctesiphon it is not heresy, but strife, self-seeking, and neglect of duty, that are censured by the Synod through the letter which we know as Demonstr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:162
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:163
verses.text: , and the errors which the Bishop of Mar Mathai combats for the benefit of those whom he addresses are the errors of the Jews who refused and resisted the creed and the customs of the Church.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:164
verses.text: There is in one place (Demonstr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:165
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:166
verses.text: 9) a passing reference to the heresiarchs of the second and third centuries, Valentinus, Manes, and Marcion; but it merely amounts to a brief statement in which the false teaching of each is summed up in a sentence, each followed by the question, Can one who holds such doctrine find acceptance before God by his fasting?  No later heresy is even mentioned.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:167
verses.text: These facts not only confirm the tradition which places him at Nineveh, but they go far to account for the obscurity in which his name and his writings lay so long.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:168
verses.text: In an age of excited controversy, these quiet hortatory discourses, marked by no striking eloquence of style or subtlety of reasoning, dealing with no burning question of the time, nor with any disputes more recent than those of the two previous centuries, or those between Jew and Christian, would hardly attain to more than a local circulation; and when they penetrated to Edessa or other such centres of Syriac theological life, would awaken but a languid interest.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:169
verses.text: That they did so penetrate is certain; for of the existing mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:170
verses.text: whence we derive their text, one (the oldest) was written in Edessa in 474, and Isaac of Antioch, who knew and imitated them, before that time, was a disciple of Zenobius of Edessa.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:171
verses.text: But the paucity of such mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:172
verses.text: , and still more the oblivion which so long covered the name of Aphrahat, prove, either, that the work failed to attain popularity—or, that it provoked some prejudice which led to its practical suppression.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:173
verses.text: It would be difficult, however, to point out anything in it to which exception could be so seriously taken as to be a bar to its acceptance.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:174
verses.text: None of the errors which so keen a critic as Georgius detected in its theology—even if we admit the justice of his censure—is such as to shock the orthodoxy of the fourth or fifth century.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:176
verses.text: Possibly Suspected of a Nestorian Tinge.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:177
verses.text: —Yet it is possible that theological prepossession may indirectly have brought about the disfavour or at least disuse into which the Demonstrations fell.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:178
verses.text: In Edessa there was an institution known as the "School of the Persians," to which as it seems disciples from Persia resorted for theological instruction.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:179
verses.text: From Ibas, Bishop of Edessa (435–457), who was infected with Nestorianism, the Nestorian taint passed to Maris, a Persian (and through him to Persia generally), and likewise to Maro, a teacher in the school.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:180
verses.text: After the death of Ibas, the Persian and others who had followed him were expelled from Edessa, by Nonnus his orthodox opponent and successor; and the school was finally closed by the next Bishop, Cyrus, in the reign of Zeno (who died 491).

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:181
verses.text: These facts may well be supposed to have raised a prejudice against all writings coming from a Persian source; and the works of "the Persian Sage," absolutely free though they are from any thought or phrase which could be construed as favouring or tending in the direction that led to the errors of Nestorius, may have come undeservedly under the ban issued against the School of the Persians and all that was connected with it, by the orthodox zeal of Cyrus.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:182
verses.text: It is probable that his writings were read in that school, and that he himself may have studied them in early life.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:183
verses.text: Prescribed in Edessa, the centre of Syriac theology, these discourses would be effectually checked in their circulation in all churches of Syriac-speaking Christendom that were anti-Nestorian.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:185
verses.text: Their Popularity in the Armenian Church.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:186
verses.text: —How the book made good and held its footing in the Armenian Church is perhaps more difficult to explain.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:187
verses.text: It is not indeed the only instance in which an author, of whom no works are extant in their original tongue, has survived and been widely known in a translation.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:188
verses.text: A notable example is that of Irenaeus, of whose great work on Heresies, so well known in its early Latin dress, but a few fragments have reached us, through citations, in Greek.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:189
verses.text: There is no obvious ecclesiastical channel through which the knowledge of the writings of Aphrahat can be supposed to have reached Armenia, unless by way of Edessa, before they fell (as above suggested) into discredit in that city.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:190
verses.text: But it is to be borne in mind that from and after the close of the fourth century "greater (i-e: Eastern) Armenia was ruled as a dependency of Persia, by Persian Kings".

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:191
verses.text: Of these the earlier at least were Christians, and their policy led them to promote the Syriac language and literature, as against the Greek, among their people; until, under the Catholicus Isaac (d.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:192
verses.text: 441), the Armenian tongue was reduced to writing (in the characters then invested by Mesrob), and a beginning made of an Armenian sacred literature by the translation of the Scriptures into Armenian from the Syriac.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:193
verses.text: Versions of the works of Syriac divines would naturally follow before long.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:194
verses.text: That among these Ephraim's Commentaries were conspicuous we have already mentioned (p.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:195
verses.text: 147):  that those of a Syriac Divine of Persian nationality should be passed over is unlikely—a Divine too of such repute as to have won the honourable title of "the Persian Sage," and who as occupant of a great Persian see was also known as Jacob of Mar Mathai, metropolitan of Nineveh.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:196
verses.text: How readily his assumed name would lead to his being confused with his far more widely known namesake of Nisibis, we have already pointed out; and it is obvious that the name, once attributed and accepted, would lend fictitious vogue to the book.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:198
verses.text: First Printed in an Armenian Version.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:199
verses.text: —The mistake of the Armenian translator became, in later times, the means of first making the work—though not the name—of Aphrahat known to European scholars.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:200
verses.text: The Armenian version, containing nineteen of the Demonstrations (XX.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:201
verses.text: being omitted), was printed at Rome in 1756, edited, with a Latin version, by Antonelli.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:202
verses.text: Its text is derived from a transcript made in 1719, after an ancient copy in the Armenian Monastery at Venice, by order of the Abbot Peter Mechitar, and presented by him to Pope Clement XI.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:203
verses.text: for the Vatican Library.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:204
verses.text: In this edition, entitled S.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:205
verses.text: Patris Jacobi Episcopi Nisibeni Sermones, the discourses are not merely ascribed to Jacob of Nisibis, but the theory is advanced by the editor, that the Armenian text is the original.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:206
verses.text: It is hardly necessary to point out that the alphabetic arrangement of the twenty-two discourses—which is not and could not be reproduced in Armenian, a language with an alphabet of thirty-eight letters—is alone sufficient to expose the impossibility of this idea.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:208
verses.text: Recovery of the Post-Syriac Original.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:209
verses.text: —The Syriac text, so long forgotten, was first discovered among the mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:210
verses.text: of the great Nitrian collection in the British Museum, by Dr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:211
verses.text: Cureton, whose name is so honourably known as a great Syriac scholar, and editor of Syriac documents.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:212
verses.text: He did not live, however, to accomplish his desire of publishing it, but bequeathed that task to his still more eminent successor, in the leadership of Syriac studies in England, the late Dr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:213
verses.text: William Wright, then assistant keeper of mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:214
verses.text: in the British Museum, and afterwards Professor of Arabic in the University of Cambridge.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:215
verses.text: To him is due the admirable editio princeps of the Syriac text of all the twenty-three Demonstrations (from the mss.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:216
verses.text: 14617 and 17182), issued in London, 1869.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:217
verses.text: He did not, however, carry out his intention of adding to this work a second volume, containing an English translation of the whole.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:218
verses.text: Since then, another edition of the series of twenty-two has been published in Paris (Firmin-Didot, 1894), as the first volume of a Patrologia Syriaca, under the general editorship of Dr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:219
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:220
verses.text: Graffin, lecturer in Syriac in the Theological Faculty of the Catholic Institute of Paris.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:221
verses.text: This excellent work includes a Latin Version, and is preceded by a learned and copious Introduction, in which all questions relating to Aphrahat and his writings are fully treated,—both of which are the work of Dom Parisot, Benedictine Priest and Monk.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:223
verses.text: Was Aphrahat Prior to Ephraim?—In thus placing Aphrahat first as their projected series of Syriac Divines, the learned editors follow the opinion which, ever since Wright published his edition, has been adopted by Syriac scholars—that Aphrahat is prior in time to Ephraim.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:224
verses.text: This is undoubtedly true (as pointed out above) in the only limited sense, that the Demonstrations are earlier by some years (the first ten by thirteen years, the remainder by five or six) than the earliest of Ephraim's writings which can be dated with certainty (namely, the first Nisibene Hymn, which belongs to 350).

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:225
verses.text: It is then assumed that Ephraim was born in the reign of Constantine, therefore not earlier than 306, and that Aphrahat was a man of advanced age when he wrote (of which there is no proof whatever), and must therefore have been born before the end of the third century—perhaps as early as 280.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:226
verses.text: It has been shown above (p.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:227
verses.text: 145) that even if we admit the authority of the Syriac Life of Ephraim, we must regard the supposed statement of his birth in Constantine's time as a mistranslation or rather perversion of the text.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:228
verses.text: Thus the argument for placing Ephraim's birth so late as 306 disappears, while for placing Aphrahat's birth no argument has been advanced, but merely conjecture; and the result is, that the two may, so far as evidence goes, be regarded as contemporary.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:229
verses.text: It is true that Barhebraeus, in his Ecclesiastical History, reckons Aphrahat as belonging to the time of Papas, who died 335; but it is to be noted that in the very same context he mentions that letters were extant purporting to be addressed by Jacob of Nisibis and Ephraim to the same Papas,—and though he admits that some discredited the genuineness of these letters, he gives no hint that Ephraim was too young to have written them.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:230
verses.text: In fact he could not do so, for in the earlier part of this History he had already named Ephraim as present at the Nicene Council in 325, and had placed his name before that of Aphrahat in including both among the contemporaries of the Great Athanasius.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:232
verses.text: His Use of Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:233
verses.text: —Concerning the canon and text of the Books of the Bible as used by Aphrahat,—a subject hardly within the scope of this Introduction—a few words must suffice.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:234
verses.text: In citing the Old Testament, he shows himself acquainted with nearly all the Books of the Jewish Canon, and with some, but not all, of the deutero-canonical books commonly called Apocrypha—with Tobit, Ecclesiasticus (and perhaps Wisdom), and Maccabees, but not Judith, Susanna, Bel and the Dragon, or Baruch.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:235
verses.text: He follows the Peshitto rather than the Greek, but not seldom departs from both; and he shows a knowledge of the Chaldee Paraphrase.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:236
verses.text: His New Testament Canon is apparently that of the Peshitto;—that is to say, he shows no signs of acquaintance with the four shorter Catholic Epistles, and in the one citation which seems to be from the Apocalypse, it has been shown to be probable that he is really referring to the Targum of Onkelos on Deut.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:237
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:239
verses.text: But he omits all reference also to the longer Catholic Epistles, except 1 John.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:240
verses.text: He also passes over (of St.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:241
verses.text: Paul's Epistles) 2 Thessalonians, Titus, and Philemon.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:242
verses.text: But as regards the last, its shortness accounts for the omission; and as to the former two, he can hardly have been unacquainted with them, inasmuch as he knew 1 Thessalonians and 1 and 2 Timothy.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:243
verses.text: He designates the writer of Hebrews as "the Apostle," probably meaning to ascribe it to St.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:244
verses.text: Paul.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:245
verses.text: In citing the Gospels, he seems sometimes to follow the Diatessaron, which, as we have said, was in the hands of his contemporary Ephraim, and which is known to have circulated largely in the East until far on in the following century.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:246
verses.text: Sometimes, however, his references seem to be to the separate Gospels as commonly read.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:247
verses.text: It cannot be claimed for the Peshitto that he always or even usually follows its text; nor yet does he uniformly agree with the Curetonian, or with the probably earlier form of the Syriac Gospel recently discovered by Mr.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:248
verses.text: Lewis.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:249
verses.text: With each of these last, however, his text has many points of coincidence.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:250
verses.text: In the rest of the New Testament, we can only say that he must have had before him a text which diverged not seldom from the Peshitto.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:252
verses.text: Literary and Theological Value of his Writings.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:253
verses.text: —From the Demonstrations, eight have been selected for the present volume, viz.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:255
verses.text: Of Faith (with Letter of an Inquirer prefixed); V.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:256
verses.text: Of Wars; VI.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:257
verses.text: Of Monks; VIII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:258
verses.text: Of the Resurrection of the Dead; X.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:259
verses.text: Of Pastors; XVII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:260
verses.text: Of Christ the Son of God; XXI.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:261
verses.text: Of Persecution; XXII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:262
verses.text: Of Death and the Latter Times.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:263
verses.text: Of these, one only (XVII.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:264
verses.text: ) is controversial,—directed against the Jews:  it is painfully inadequate in the treatment of its great theme,—so inadequate as to suggest the surmise that doubts may have arisen about the orthodoxy of the writer, such as to discredit his works, and to account for the neglect in which they lay (as we have seen) for centuries.

verses.name: Aphrahat the Persian Sage 1:265
verses.text: But in all his writings his mastery of the Scriptures, of the Old Testament especially, is conspicuous; and in many of them, especially in those of a hortatory character, there is much force of earnest persuasiveness, rising at times into eloquence.
